name: Network Security
description: In Phase 2, you learned how networking works—IP addresses, ports, DNS, all that good stuff. Now we're going to apply that knowledge to keep your cloud resources safe. Your Journal API's database shouldn't be accessible from the public internet, and your API should only accept traffic the way you intend. Let's set up the network boundaries that make that possible.

learning_steps.description: You already know how networking works from Phase 2. Now see how your cloud provider implements it with Virtual Private Clouds (VPCs). Pick your provider and read through the overview.
These videos show how to actually set up network security in your cloud provider. Follow along in your own account if you can—seeing the console makes it click.
learning_steps.title: Network Security in Action

learning_steps.description: These are the standards professionals use. You don't need to memorize them, but they're great references when you're designing your network in the capstone.

A VPC is your own private network inside the cloud—think of it as your own little data center. Here's how it works:

- **Isolation**: Your resources live in their own network, separate from everyone else's
- **Subnets**: You divide your VPC into smaller segments (public-facing stuff vs. private stuff)
- **Route Tables**: Rules that control where traffic can flow
- **Internet Gateways**: The door to the public internet—only open it where you need to

For your Journal API, the API server goes in a public subnet (it needs to receive requests), but the database goes in a private subnet (it should only talk to your API).

learning_steps.action: Study: Security Groups vs Network ACLs
learning_steps.description:
These are the two types of firewalls you get in the cloud. Understanding the difference trips up a lot of people, so let's be clear:

**Security Groups (Stateful):**
- Like a firewall around a single resource (your API server, your database)
- Allow rules only—everything is blocked by default
- Stateful means if you allow traffic in, the response is automatically allowed out

**Network ACLs (Stateless):**
- Like a firewall around an entire subnet
- Has both allow AND deny rules
- Stateless means you have to explicitly allow both inbound AND outbound traffic

For your Journal API: a security group on your API server allows port 443 (HTTPS) from anywhere. A security group on your database allows port 5432 (PostgreSQL) only from your API server's security group.

This is about putting things in the right "rooms" of your cloud network:

- **Public Subnets**: Resources that need to face the internet—like your load balancer
- **Private Subnets**: Resources that only need internal access—like your Journal API server and database
- **Isolated Subnets**: Maximum lockdown—no internet access at all, for highly sensitive resources

A good setup for your Journal API: load balancer in the public subnet, API server in a private subnet, database in an isolated subnet.

Load balancers aren't just for distributing traffic—they're also a key security tool:

- **Application Load Balancers**: Handle HTTP/HTTPS, can inspect traffic and block attacks
- **Network Load Balancers**: Handle raw TCP/UDP at high speed
- **Security features**: SSL termination (handles HTTPS for your API), DDoS protection, access logging

Even if you're only running one instance of your Journal API, a load balancer adds SSL termination and an extra layer of protection.
learning_steps.title: Load Balancers and Traffic Management

learning_steps.description:
If the Phase 2 networking content had you thinking about physical hardware, here's how it maps to the cloud:

- Physical routers/switches → Virtual routers, VPC gateways (all software-defined)
- Hardware firewalls → Security Groups, NACLs (configured via console or code)
- Physical network segmentation → Subnets, VPCs (logical boundaries, same security benefits)
- Network cables → Virtual connections, VPC peering (no physical infrastructure to manage)

The concepts are the same—the implementation is just code instead of hardware.
